Title: Negotiating
Book Description: From negotiating a scene to negotiating a relationship- come learn some great lessons in the art of negotiation.

Title: Influence of Anime in Media
Book Description: Fans of anime and manga know it's influenced our lives- but what about the other kinds of media we consume? Television- music- and games draw more and more inspiration from anime every day- and not always in obvious ways.

Title: Changing Demographics of Comics Readers
Book Description: Both Marvel and DC have engineered major reboots in the last few years to bring in a new demographic of comics readers.  How has that demographic changed?

Title: So You Want to Get a Degree in Comics?
Book Description: Have you ever wanted to write an essay on the Marvel universe? How about an honors thesis or a dissertation? This panel discusses the ins and outs of studying comics at the university level and introduces the fundamentals of comics studies.

Title: Teaching with Comics
Book Description: With visual culture becoming more and more integral to our lives- teachers are turning to comics as a new source for pedagogical material. This panel discusses strategies for integrating comics into elementary- high school and university teaching.

Title: Cosplay Hacks Part 1
Book Description: Do you have a great costume idea but can't find a pattern or the ability to make it? I have some great advice and techniques that will help you get through it all. We will be addressing alteration of existing items or patterns- pattern creation- sewing alternatives- and some clever tricks to help you on your way. Part 1 of 2.

Title: Crocheting 101 DIY
Book Description: Come learn how to crochet!  Bring your yarn and hooks (or some of your stash to help start out new people!). Everyone is welcome to discuss different techniques and stitches. Come learn some new skills or help to teach others new skills.

Title: Basic Skills for working with electronics.
Book Description: This presentation will cover the very very basics of DC circuit theory and the skills needed to cut and prep wire and then solder it together or to a component.

Title: Backcountry Camping
Book Description: Camping can be something besides a place to park your RV.  Learn about what it takes to go someplace where your phone has no signal. How to eat- how to sleep- how to stay warm and dry.  Where you can go within an easy drive from metro Detroit.  We'll  also discuss some of the reasons why you might want to head into the back country.

Title: Beyond the Binary
Presenters: Jen Schwartz, Matt Sweet, Max Issac
Book Description: Let's look into our own personal identities beyond the gender binary.

Title: Geek Cred - How to Be a Better Geek
Book Description: Fandom should bring people together- not be used as a cudgel.  How can the geek community become more inclusive?

Title: How to Poison Your Muse â€“ the Toxic Twins of Talent and Art.
Book Description: We'll discuss how common ideas about talent and art sabotage our creativity. What are these traps- and how can we avoid them? A discussion for artists- authors- musicians- and anyone else who wants to create good stuff.

Title: Party Planning
Book Description: Whether it's a formal dinner or gaming night- how to prepare for- run- and still enjoy your get-together.

Title: Staying Fit On The Go
Book Description: Join us on a discussion about different ways to stay healthy and active no matter where you are. Topics will also include things you can do right now during the convention.

Title: Evoking Emotions, Provoking Readers
Presenters: Merrie Haskell, Cindy Spencer Pape, Ken MacGregor
Book Description: Creating authentic characters who seem to experience a full range of believable emotions is only half the equation in character-building.  How can we use character emotions to evoke real feelings in our readers? What other tricks are there?

Title: History in Speculative Fiction (and other literature)
Presenters: Clif Flynt, Steven Saus, Nicole Castle, Robert Kroese
Book Description: The historical details can bring a story to life or bog it down. What's the right balance?

Title: Self-Publishing 2016
Presenters: Michael Lucas, Jen Haeger, Christopher Purrett, Alex Kourvo, Robert Kroese
Book Description: This panel discusses today's self-publishing options and business models. Our panelists include authors who are both self- and traditionally published- in fiction and nonfiction- including people who are making an income entirely by self-publishing. We'll discuss why we made the choice to self-publish- the pitfalls and lessons learned- and which business choices we've made on our respective self-publishing efforts.

Title: Real-world Pandemic and deliberate extinctions: ending polio and Guinea worm
Book Description: Thanks to sustained public-health measures and health advocates willing to risk their lives- humanity is on the verge of winning two real-world games of Pandemic.  Polio- which once paralyzed 1000 children around the world every day- is now endemic only in two countries.  Guinea worm- a 80-cm long parasite associated with stagnant water- has gone from 3.5 million cases annually in the mid-1980s to only 22 cases in 2015. Jennifer Hamilton MD will talk about the human suffering associated with these diseases- the ongoing efforts to eradicate them- and policies that help support reduction of infectious diseases in general.

Title: Reroot Pontiac: Developing Interest in Awesome, an Investment in our Future
Book Description: ReRoot Pontiac- a newly founded non-profit located in Pontiac- MI would like to share its mission. We are a group of students- scientists-  gardeners and entrepreneurs focused on developing interest in science- technology- engineering and mathematics. To achieve this we are designing and building interactive spaces containing examples of sustainable energies and natural systems to promote experiential learning.

Title: BOF: Deployment and Testing
Book Description: Come share your experiences in deploying and testing software at this Birds of a Feather (unmoderated event).

Title: Forget About Operating System, is the Type of Chip Architecture Still Relevant?
Book Description: With the increasing number of single board computers such as the Beaglebone Black- The Chip- Raspberry Pi- Orange Pi- and Banana Pi along with numerous Linux and other alternative operating systems to run on them is it still that important to have an x86 processor in your next computer.  This panel will include an open discussion on the numerous platforms in existence along with the homebrew and open source support for older computer chip sets such as the PowerPC.
